context: So tell me , what's the difference between the Board of Directors , the CEO , and the stockholders ? They all seems ot be the same group of people to me ...
target: No , there's a definite difference . You know , the stockholders are the people who own the company ... they're the financial control system . Then there's the CEO -- the chief executive officer . He's the hot shot , the main guy who is the boss . If there is only one person with absolute power in the organization , everyone knows that the power will go to their head . It's too dangerous . That's the reason for a Board of Directors . The board is made up of people who are experts in the industry . They could be related to the organization , but more commonly , they are independent and non-biased .

context: I am just devastated!  My boyfriend broke up with me last night!  I'm still crying!
target: Thank you for sharing. I'm sorry to hear that. It sounds like you have the metaphorical "broken heart"... with all that intense emotional, maybe even physical, stress and pain you're probably feeling.

target: It what makes you a part of the human race, having those feelings.. it's a cross-cultural concept that's been around for at least 3,000 years when talking about losing someone you desire, or who you loved. Time heals all wounds, as they say. But there is such a thing as "broken heart syndrome," where physical damage happens to the heart. You should monitor yourself closely if you don't start feeling better with time.

context: It what makes you a part of the human race, having those feelings.. it's a cross-cultural concept that's been around for at least 3,000 years when talking about losing someone you desire, or who you loved. context: I couldn't even go to work today, I am so stressed! I hate him!!  I know that time will help, but right now I am so miserable!
target: Well.. take some positive stock in what you're feeling. That emotional pain you're feeling from your broken heart--not only is it natural, but it's believed to be part of the survival instinct. Your body wants you to maintain your close social relationships, and you feel pain when they're lost. It's classic "social-attachment system" theory. You're human!

target: Haha. Good point. Well, like I've been trying to say, it's a universal concept, and many cultures use the same word to describe the physical pain and feelings that come with their relationship loss. Throughout time, they made it through okay, and I'm sure you will, too.

So, just monitor the symptoms.
